bestBHT.bht: They cast him out of the vineyard, much like how Hebrews 13:11-13 depicts the casting out of Jesus outside the camp. This rejection of Jesus as the Messiah is akin to denying his Jewish heritage, going so far as to claim he was a Samaritan. This act of killing the Prince of life and the Lord of glory, who was the rightful heir of all things, must have deeply incensed and provoked God, who had his own Son's life taken away.

John Gill: Rejected him as the Messiah, even denied that he was of the Jewish nation; said he was a Samaritan, and delivered him to the Gentiles that were without..."
Killed him; the Prince of life, the Lord of glory, and heir of all things..."
At whose solicitations the life of his Son, and heir, was taken away; by which he must be greatly provoked and incensed.

bhtAttempts.bht: They cast him out of the vineyard, much like how Hebrews 13:11-13 depicts the casting out of Jesus outside the camp. This rejection of Jesus as the Messiah is akin to denying his Jewish heritage, going so far as to claim he was a Samaritan. Ultimately, they handed him over to the Gentiles. This act of killing the Prince of life and the Lord of glory, who was the rightful heir of all things, must have deeply incensed and provoked God, who had his own Son's life taken away.

They cast him out of the vineyard, much like how Hebrews 13:11-13 depicts the casting out of Jesus outside the camp. This rejection of Jesus as the Messiah is akin to denying his Jewish heritage, going so far as to claim he was a Samaritan. This act of killing the Prince of life and the Lord of glory, who was the rightful heir of all things, must have deeply incensed and provoked God, who had his own Son's life taken away.

They cast him out of the vineyard, much like how Hebrews 13:11-13 depicts the casting out of Jesus outside the camp. This rejection of Jesus as the Messiah is akin to denying his Jewish heritage, going so far as to claim he was a Samaritan. This act of killing the Prince of life and the Lord of glory, who was the rightful heir of all things, must have deeply incensed and provoked God, who had his own Son's life taken away.

They cast him out of the vineyard, just as Hebrews 13:11-13 illustrates the expulsion of Jesus outside the camp. This rejection, denying his Jewish lineage, even claiming him to be a Samaritan, led to his delivery to the Gentiles. The profound offense committed by killing the Prince of life, the Lord of glory and rightful heir, inevitably provoked and angered God. This act of taking away the life of his own Son would certainly have stirred great indignation.

Jesus was cast out of the vineyard, reminiscent of the account in Hebrews 13:11-13 where he was also expelled outside the camp. This act of rejection involved denying his Jewish heritage, even going as far as accusing him of being a Samaritan. Ultimately, he was handed over to the Gentiles. The gravity of the situation cannot be understated — the killing of the Prince of life, the Lord of glory, and the rightful heir of all things would have surely provoked and incensed God.
